Up and coming events

"On the last day of their quarantine, a wealthy couple's house is invaded by two strangers - a sailor and a girl who might not be what she seems. And so another month of quarantine begins." Or so the synopsis of Naomi Wallace's play 'One Flea Spare' says, which starts at York Theatre Royal this month (Thumbnail credit One Flea Spare, courtesy of York Theatre Royal)

The Mott Collection - "Loud Flash: British Punk on Paper"

The Haunch of Venison's current exhibition is an entertaining, raucous, brash, anarchic rampage through the rebellious era of the British Punk movement (Thumbnail credit TM0077. Chelsea, The Fall, The Snivelling Shits, Gig Poster, The Music Machine, London 1978)

Stomp

3pm. Ambassadors Theatre, Leicester Square. A surprisingly quaint and delicate little venue in light of the spectacle's reputation. On stage: caging, water butts, saucepans, drainpipes, stop signs, go signs, signs of a stomp-fest well in thumping order

Anne Boleyn

Howard Brenton's exhilarant <em>Anne Boleyn</em> provides a refreshing addition to The Globe's potentially dry summer season, Kings & Rogues (Thumbnail credit Miranda Raison in Anne Boleyn by Howard Brenton. Photo credit: Manuel Harlan)

Charm//Offensive

Suitable for sketch show veterans or those (like myself) who are not attracted to the work of 'comedians', <em>Charm//Offensive</em> offers exactly what its edgy label presents (Thumbnail credit Image credit: Greg Bartlett)

Into-Flora

Jewellery curator Kath Libbert discusses her latest exhibition (Thumbnail credit Artist Natalya Pinchuk's work is all about growth: Number Two Growth. All images copyright Kath Libbert Gallery.)

1:1 - Architects Build Small Spaces

It is said that 'interactive art' is for children. After a trip to the Victoria and Albert Museum's current exhibition 1:1 - Architects Build Small Spaces, I can only beg to differ (Thumbnail credit 'Ark' by Rintala Eggertsson Architects)

A World Observed

A World Observed is the first major retrospective of London- based photographer Dorothy Bohm, now widely recognised as one of the doyennes of British photography (Thumbnail credit Lisbon, Portugal, 1963. Photograph by Dorothy Bohm)

That Face

Shocking is a completely inadequate word to use when describing Polly Stenham's two-act debut 'tragi-comedy' (Thumbnail credit Frances Barber as Martha)

Staging an Intervention

Acclaimed artist Susan Stockwell talks to Beth Walton about sending art out into the public arena (Thumbnail credit Photography by Shannon Tofts)

Sean Scully: Works from the 1980s

Few things bug me more than bad grammar (Thumbnail credit Sean Scully, Without, 1988)

Alice Neel: Painted Truths

There is something almost frightening walking into the Whitechapel Gallery's new retrospective on Alice Neel

Exposed: Voyeurism, Surveillance & the Camera

In a desperate attempt to escape the oppressive muggy heat of July in London, I have begun to seek solace in the cool and assuredly calming spaces of its art galleries

Louise Bourgeois dies aged 98

On May 29th 2010 it was announced that Louise Bourgeois, world-renowned sculptor and artist had passed away aged 98 from a heart attack (Thumbnail credit Maman, Collection Tate Modern, London, 1999; Copyright: Marcus Leith)

Bepo

Perhaps one method of defining art is as something which becomes more than the sum of its parts

Kodac Kulture

Kodac Kulture the third and final exhibition of term to open at The Norman Rea last week completes the galleries programme of interactive and student friendly shows for summer

Rob Ryan on his growing art and design empire

By James Bithell

Rob Ryan has no problem with his art going on a pair of knickers. Beth Walton asks what it's like to be the main man behind his growing art and design empire

Lowenna Waters

I recently turned 21, and for that landmark of a birthday, my dearest granny very thoughtfully got me a subscription to The Spectator magazine. I am not sure if you are acquainted with such mentioned enigma, so I shall expand

Arts in depth

Marnie Richards talks to Tony Wild about his debut novel, The Moonstone Legacy (Thumbnail credit Tony Wild)

Up and coming events

This month two fantastic summer shows open at the Barbican in London - the first of which, 'The Surreal House', explores the power and mystery of the house in our collective imagination (Thumbnail credit OMA, Villa Dall'Ava, 1991)

Going through the Mil: Modern Literature

f someone, under the age of 75 and living in the West, were to say to me- "Twilight? Never heard of it," I think I'd kiss them, while weeping with joy, before the heart attack could cut me off

Company

From the house musicians to the play's director, across the board, the cast of Company are a collection of very talented individuals indeed.

Interview with Jonathan Kerridge-Phipps

"There's no small talk in Pinter": <em>Old Times</em>

Yellow Moon

'Yellow Moon' is the perfect example of 'less is more'

Saved

The second instalment of the week 7 double bill, Saved, is undoubtedly worth watching. It is a fanatically gritty tale, with a superb cast

Billy Elliot

Billy Elliot is one of those shows which will stick in your mind a long time to come

dinnerladies

The much anticipated stage-adaptation of Victoria Wood's classic comedy Sitcom, Dinner Ladies, opened with an onslaught of sexual innuendos

PLOTS

Last week following on from their Academy style summer show, Light, The Norman Rea Gallery opened their second exhibition of the term PLOTS a two part display beginning in the main gallery space and continuing outside with an interactive installation

Howling Moon

York, I urge you go see 'Howling Moon'

York Theatre Royal Comedy Night

I'm not sure there are many places in York that you can have more fun for as little as PS5 (Thumbnail credit Phil Nicol )
